content: The Act may be cited as the "Berta Caceres Human Rights in Honduras Act". Congress finds that the Honduran police are corrupt and commit human rights abuses with impunity, including torture, rape, illegal detention, and murder. The New York Times revealed documents showing top police officials ordered the killings of drug-crime investigators, implicating high-ranking government officials. Individuals in the police with documented records of human rights abuses continue to operate freely. The New York Times suggested that high-ranking government officials in Honduras were manipulating revelations for corrupt purposes. International human rights bodies reported that the Honduran military and police commit human rights abuses, including killings, with impunity. The Associated Press documented death squad activity by police, and Human Rights Watch highlighted chronic use of lethal force by the national police with investigations marred by inefficiency and corruption. The Honduran police have been involved in death squad activity, with investigations into abuses marred by inefficiency and corruption. Efforts to clean up the police have largely failed, with minimal progress in prosecuting those involved in human rights violations. Efforts to clean up the Honduran police have largely failed, with minimal progress in prosecuting those involved in corruption and human rights abuses. The Fifteenth Battalion of the Honduran Armed Forces allegedly participated in killings of small-farmer activists in the Aguan Valley. Rights Action documented the Fifteenth Battalion of the Honduran Armed Forces allegedly participating in killings of small-farmer activists in the Aguan Valley since 2000. Human Rights Watch confirmed in 2015 that these killings went unpunished, with only one private actor convicted. Key activists continue to be assassinated, such as Jose Angel Flores and Silmer Dionisio George in 2016. The Honduran Navy reportedly killed two Garifuna Afro-Indigenous men, Joel Palacios Lino and Elvis Armando Garcia, in December 2015 while they were digging a car out of the sand on a beach. The case remains unresolved. Efforts to reform the justice system have made little progress, with the judiciary and police remaining largely ineffective and marred by corruption and abuse. The assassination of Berta Caceres in 2016 highlights the human rights crisis in Honduras, showing the government's deep complicity. The Secretary of the Treasury to oppose loans for Honduran police and military at multilateral development banks. SEC. 4. Conditions for lifting suspensions and restrictions. The Act will end when the Secretary of State certifies that Honduras has pursued legal action for various murders and human rights violations. Honduras must investigate and prosecute military and police forces for human rights violations, withdraw the military from domestic policing, and protect the rights of various activists. Honduras must ensure civilian control over domestic police functions, protect the rights of activists, and establish a capable judicial system to prosecute human rights abuses by police and military members.
